name: Macro X-ray Fluorescence Scanning
summary: MA-XRF is a non-destructive elemental imaging technique that scans an X-ray beam across artwork surfaces to create spatial distribution maps of elements like lead, mercury, iron, copper, and calcium. The technique reveals hidden compositions, artist alterations (pentimenti), and pigment layering by detecting characteristic X-ray fluorescence from elements in paint layers, allowing researchers to "see" beneath the surface without sampling. MA-XRF has become one of the most important tools in technical art history since the 2000s.
keyApplications: Pigment identification and spatial mapping across entire paintings
Detection of underpaintings, pentimenti, and compositional changes
Artist attribution through painting technique analysis
Degradation mapping (e.g., lead soap formation, pigment alteration)
Study of artist's palette and material choices over time

fundamentalPhysics.principle:
When X-rays with sufficient energy strike atoms in a material, they can eject inner-shell electrons (typically K or L shell). This creates an unstable electronic configuration. An electron from a higher shell fills the vacancy, releasing energy as a characteristic X-ray photon with energy specific to the element and transition type. By detecting these fluorescent X-rays and mapping their intensity across a surface, MA-XRF creates elemental distribution images.

The technique is based on three fundamental processes:

1. **Photoelectric absorption**: Incident X-rays eject inner-shell electrons

2. **Atomic relaxation**: Outer-shell electrons fill vacancies

3. **Fluorescent emission**: Characteristic X-rays are emitted

The depth of analysis depends on X-ray energy and material composition, typically sampling 10-200 μm in paint layers.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: X-ray fluorescence occurs when incident X-rays have sufficient energy to ionize inner-shell electrons (K or L shells). The resulting characteristic X-ray emission is element-specific, with energies ranging from ~1 keV (light elements) to ~100 keV (heavy elements).

variables.meaning: principal quantum number of inner shell (1 for K-shell)
principal quantum number of outer shell (2 for K-alpha transition)
attenuation coefficient for outgoing fluorescent X-rays

fundamentalPhysics.interactionDepth: The sampling depth is energy-dependent and material-dependent. For oil paint: Light elements (Ca, K) 20-50 μm; Medium Z (Fe, Cu) 50-100 μm; Heavy elements (Pb, Hg) 100-200 μm. Factors affecting penetration: Higher energy X-rays penetrate deeper; Lower atomic number elements have shallower information depth; Matrix composition (oil vs. tempera vs. watercolor); Paint thickness and layering.
fundamentalPhysics.spatialResolution: Lateral Resolution (x-y): Typical 0.5-2 mm spot size; High-resolution systems: 50-200 μm. Limiting factors: X-ray beam collimation/focusing, source-sample-detector geometry, step size during scanning, count statistics. Depth Resolution (z): Poor depth discrimination in standard MA-XRF; Total sampling depth: 10-200 μm (energy and matrix dependent); Confocal XRF can achieve ~10-50 μm depth resolution.
fundamentalPhysics.detectionLimit: Typical detection limits: 10-100 ppm (parts per million) for medium-Z elements. Major elements (>1%): Quantifiable with standards. Minor elements (0.1-1%): Semi-quantitative. Trace elements (<0.1%): Detection possible but challenging. Dynamic range: 10⁴-10⁶ depending on element and acquisition time. Best sensitivity: Elements with Z = 20-30 (Ca to Zn). Poor sensitivity: Very light elements (Z < 14, Na) and very heavy (Z > 83).

instrumentation.source: X-ray tube (most common), or synchrotron radiation (research applications). X-ray tube specifications: Anode materials: Rhodium (Rh), Tungsten (W), Molybdenum (Mo), Silver (Ag). Operating voltage: 20-50 kV typical (adjustable). Current: 0.1-1.0 mA. Spot size: 50 μm - 2 mm diameter. Power: 4-50 W. Polychromatic vs. monochromatic: Standard MA-XRF uses polychromatic (white) X-rays; Filters (Al, Cu) used to shape spectrum and reduce low-energy component; Some systems offer monochromatic excitation for specific elements.
instrumentation.detector: Primary detector type: Silicon Drift Detector (SDD). Active area: 7-80 mm². Energy resolution: 125-145 eV FWHM at Mn Kα (5.9 keV). Count rate: up to 10⁵-10⁶ cps (with pileup correction). Energy range: 1-40 keV (depending on model). Operating temperature: Peltier-cooled (-20 to -40°C). Alternative detectors: Si-PIN diodes (lower resolution, higher count rate), HPGe detectors (better resolution, requires liquid N₂ cooling), Multi-element SDD arrays (for faster acquisition).
instrumentation.optics: Polycapillary optics: Bundles of curved glass capillaries; Focus X-rays to 50-200 μm spots; Gain factor: 10-1000× in flux density; Working distance: 5-20 mm. Collimators: Single-hole or multi-hole apertures; Materials: W, Pb, Pt; Define beam size: 0.5-2 mm typical. Filters: Aluminum (Al) 100-500 μm thick, reduces low-energy X-rays; Copper (Cu) for specific applications; Reduces detector dead time, improves peak-to-background ratio.
criticalComponents: Motorized XY scanning stage (Travel range: 50 × 50 cm to 200 × 200 cm, Step resolution: 10-50 μm, Positioning accuracy: ±50 μm)
Scanner head/gantry (Holds X-ray tube, detector, positioning optics, Weight: 5-30 kg, Adjustable height for varying painting sizes)
High-voltage power supply (Stable voltage regulation <0.01% drift, Current control, Safety interlocks)
Multi-channel analyzer (MCA) (Digital pulse processor, 2048-4096 channels, Real-time spectrum acquisition)
Positioning sensors (Laser distance sensors for surface topography, Maintain constant working distance, Accuracy: ±0.1-1 mm)
Video camera (Visible-light imaging for registration, Sample positioning verification)
Shielding and safety systems (Lead curtains or enclosure, X-ray interlock systems, Radiation monitors)
Computer and control software (Motor control, Spectrum acquisition, Real-time data processing)
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration:
**Lab-based system:**
- Vertical gantry with motorized XY stage (easel-mounted paintings)
- Rh-anode X-ray tube (50 kV, 0.6 mA, 1 mm spot)
- Polycapillary optics focusing to 200 μm
- SDD detector (30 mm², 145 eV resolution)
- Working distance: 1.5 cm
- Al filter (250 μm)
- Lead shielding enclosure
- Footprint: 2 × 2 × 2.5 m (width × depth × height)

**Portable/transportable configuration:**
- Lightweight scanner head (<10 kg)
- Mounted on tripod or adjustable frame
- Can be positioned in front of wall-mounted paintings
- Smaller scan areas (typically up to 50 × 50 cm per setup)
- Battery-powered options available

samplePreparation: No sample preparation required - completely non-destructive, in-situ technique
Painting can be scanned in frame (frame may cast shadows)
Dust or loose particulates should be gently removed (conservator)
Glass/acrylic glazing must be removed (causes scatter and absorption)
Surface should be accessible and relatively flat
Easel-mounted paintings: ideal for vertical scanners
Horizontal surface scanning: for large or fragile objects
Irregular surfaces: requires distance monitoring and mapping

Pre-scan documentation: High-resolution visible-light photography for registration, Condition documentation, Surface topography mapping if available, UV and IR imaging recommended (for comparison/registration)
methodology.measurementProtocol:
**STEP 1: Setup and Safety (15-30 minutes)**
- Position painting in scanner frame or mount portable scanner
- Ensure radiation shielding is in place
- Verify interlock systems functional
- Post radiation warning signs
- Clear area of unnecessary personnel

**STEP 2: Alignment and Registration (15-30 minutes)**
- Acquire visible-light reference photograph
- Position scanner head at safe working distance
- Use laser distance sensor to map surface topography
- Define coordinate system and scan boundaries
- Mark fiducial points for registration
- Critical parameters: Working distance accuracy ±0.5 mm

**STEP 3: System Calibration (10-20 minutes)**
- Measure reference spectrum on calibration standard (brass, stainless steel)
- Verify characteristic peak positions (Kα, Kβ)
- Check energy calibration across full spectrum
- Verify detector resolution and peak shape
- Adjust tube voltage/current if needed
- Typical parameters: Calibration standard: NIST 1577c bovine liver or copper; Acquisition time: 60 seconds live time; Accept if energy calibration <10 eV error

**STEP 4: Test Scan (20-40 minutes)**
- Scan small region (5 × 5 cm) at planned resolution
- Verify adequate count rates (10,000-100,000 cps total)
- Check for detector saturation or pileup (keep ICR/OCR ratio >0.5)
- Verify elements of interest have sufficient statistics (>1000 peak counts)
- Adjust dwell time per point if needed
- Typical test parameters: Step size: 1 mm; Dwell time: 50-200 ms/pixel; Examine Ca, Fe, Cu, Pb, Hg peaks

**STEP 5: Full Scan Acquisition (2-24 hours depending on size/resolution)**
- Begin automated raster scan
- Monitor progress and data quality in real-time
- Software automatically saves spectra at each pixel
- Periodically check: Stage position accuracy, Count rate stability, Temperature stability, Computer storage space, No mechanical obstructions
- Pause/resume capability for long scans

**Typical parameters for painting scan:**
- Scan area: 50 × 40 cm (typical small painting)
- Step size: 1 mm (can go to 0.5 mm or 2 mm)
- Dwell time: 100 ms per pixel
- Total pixels: 50 × 40 × 10 = 200,000 points
- Total time: 200,000 × 0.1 s = 20,000 s ≈ 5.5 hours
- Data size: ~10-50 GB (full spectral data)

**STEP 6: Quality Assurance During Scan**
- Monitor deadtime: keep <40%
- Check stage positioning: verify no drift
- Inspect emerging elemental maps for artifacts
- Verify uniform intensity across scan (no dropouts)

**STEP 7: Post-Scan Procedures (15 minutes)**
- Complete radiation safety shutdown
- Return X-ray shielding to safe configuration
- Back up raw data files
- Acquire post-scan visible image to verify no movement
- Document any issues or observations
- Remove radiation warning signs

**STEP 8: Data Export and Archiving (30 minutes)**
- Export full spectral datasets
- Generate preliminary elemental maps
- Archive raw data with metadata
- Document scan parameters in laboratory notebook
- Link to object database/accession records

methodology.calibration:
**Energy Calibration:**
- Standards used: Copper foil (Cu Kα = 8.048 keV, Cu Kβ = 8.905 keV), Brass (Cu + Zn lines), Multi-element standards (Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mo)
- Frequency: Daily before measurements, verify weekly
- Procedure: 1) Acquire 60 s spectrum on Cu foil, 2) Identify Cu Kα and Kβ peaks, 3) Apply linear energy calibration: E = a + b × channel, 4) Verify other element peaks within ±20 eV, 5) Save calibration coefficients

**Intensity/Response Calibration:**
- Standards: NIST SRM glass standards (K411, K412, etc.) or certified paint samples
- Purpose: Relate count rates to concentrations
- Frequency: Monthly or when quantification needed
- Limitations: Matrix effects make absolute quantification difficult without standards matching artwork matrix

**Spatial Calibration:**
- Method: Scan object with known dimensions or grid pattern
- Verify: Stage positioning accuracy and repeatability
- Frequency: Initial setup, then verify quarterly

**Validation Checks:**
- Scan known reference painting or test panel
- Compare elemental maps to previous measurements
- Verify reproducibility within ±10%
qualityControl: Pre-scan checks: X-ray tube warm-up complete (30 min), Detector cooled to operating temperature, Energy calibration verified, Working distance sensors functional, Radiation shielding in place
During scan checks: Real-time elemental map inspection for artifacts, Count rate monitoring (stability within ±5%), Stage position verification every 30 minutes, Temperature monitoring of electronics
Post-scan checks: Verify complete scan coverage (no missed rows), Check for motion artifacts, Inspect spectrum quality at random pixels, Verify data file integrity

Common artifacts to watch for: Striping (stage motion irregularities), Hotspots (cosmic rays, electrical noise), Edge effects (beam partially off sample), Shadowing (from frame or surface irregularities), Intensity gradients (working distance variations)

Troubleshooting: Low count rates (increase voltage/current or reduce distance), Peak broadening (recalibrate detector or allow longer cool-down), Striping in maps (reduce step size, clean bearings, check grounding), Pileup artifacts (reduce tube current, increase distance), Spectral artifacts (check filter position, improve shielding geometry)

dataAnalysis.rawDataFormat:
**File Formats:**
- HDF5 (Hierarchical Data Format) - most common for modern systems
- Multi-file structures (one spectrum per pixel as ASCII or binary)
- Proprietary formats: Bruker SPX, ARTAX, M6 formats
- Standard formats: EMSA/ISO 22029 for spectral exchange

**Data Structure:**
- 3D datacube: [x-position, y-position, energy-spectrum]
- Typical dimensions: 500 × 400 × 2048 (x × y × energy channels)
- Each pixel contains full energy spectrum (1-40 keV)
- Metadata: scan parameters, timestamps, position encoders

**Typical File Sizes:**
- Small scan (10 × 10 cm, 1 mm step): 1-5 GB
- Typical painting (50 × 40 cm, 1 mm step): 10-50 GB
- High-resolution scan (0.1 mm step): 100-500 GB
preprocessing: Dead-time correction: Apply correction for detector dead time. Formula: True_counts = Measured_counts / (1 - deadtime_fraction). Most systems apply automatically
Energy calibration verification: Check calibration at each pixel or subsample. Correct drift if necessary using prominent peaks (Ca, Fe, Cu)
Spectral alignment: Align all spectra to common energy scale. Correct for gain drift during long scans
Background subtraction: Remove continuum background (Bremsstrahlung). Methods: SNIP (Statistics-sensitive Non-linear Iterative Peak-clipping), polynomial fitting. Leave characteristic peaks intact
Pileup correction: Identify and correct sum peaks (e.g., Pb Lα + Pb Lα). Modern SDDs have hardware pileup rejection
Normalization: Normalize to Compton scatter peak (for tube spectrum variations). Or normalize to dwell time and tube current. Critical for comparing scans acquired with different parameters
Cosmic ray / spike removal: Identify outlier pixels with abnormally high counts. Apply median filter or manual removal
dataAnalysis.analysisWorkflow:
**STEP 1: Spectral Visualization and Peak Identification (30-60 minutes)**
- Load full spectral datacube
- Generate sum spectrum (all pixels added)
- Identify all elements present using characteristic peak energies
- Typical elements in paintings: Light (Si, P, S, Cl, K, Ca), Medium (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, As), Heavy (Sr, Cd, Sn, Sb, Ba, Hg, Pb)
- Check for peak overlaps (e.g., Pb Lα at 10.55 keV overlaps with As Kα at 10.54 keV)
- Reference databases: X-ray data booklet (LBNL), Elam database

**STEP 2: Region of Interest (ROI) Definition**
- For each identified element, define energy ROI around characteristic peak
- Typical ROIs: Ca Kα: 3.6-3.8 keV, Fe Kα: 6.3-6.5 keV, Cu Kα: 8.0-8.1 keV, Pb Lα: 10.4-10.7 keV, Hg Lα: 9.8-10.1 keV
- Set background ROIs on either side of peak
- Use appropriate K or L lines depending on excitation energy

**STEP 3: Generate Elemental Distribution Maps**
- Integrate counts within each ROI for every pixel
- Subtract background contribution
- Create 2D intensity map for each element
- Apply false color scheme for visualization
- Typical color maps: grayscale, thermal (yellow-red), or element-specific colors

**STEP 4: Deconvolution and Quantification (optional, advanced)**
- Full-spectrum fitting using: PyMca (Python-based, open-source), AXIL (IAEA), Fundamental parameters method
- Deconvolve overlapping peaks (e.g., Pb L-lines, As Kα)
- Calculate semi-quantitative concentrations (requires standards and matrix corrections)
- Equation: Concentration ∝ (Peak intensity) / (Sensitivity factor × Matrix correction)

**STEP 5: Image Processing and Enhancement**
- Adjust brightness/contrast for visualization
- Apply spatial filters (Gaussian smooth, median filter) to reduce noise
- Register to visible-light photograph
- Overlay multiple element maps (RGB composites)
- Example RGB composite: Red channel: Pb distribution, Green channel: Cu distribution, Blue channel: Fe distribution

**STEP 6: Correlation Analysis**
- Examine spatial correlations between elements
- Scatter plots: element X vs. element Y intensity
- Identify pigment mixtures and layer structures
- Principal component analysis (PCA) for pattern recognition

**STEP 7: Pigment Identification**
- Combine elemental information with known pigment compositions:
  - Lead white: Pb
  - Vermilion: Hg, S
  - Azurite: Cu
  - Malachite: Cu
  - Verdigris: Cu
  - Smalt: Co, (K, As)
  - Yellow ochre: Fe
  - Red ochre: Fe
  - Prussian blue: Fe
  - Cadmium yellow: Cd
  - Chrome yellow: Pb, Cr
  - Emerald green: Cu, As
  - Cinnabar: Hg
  - Naples yellow: Pb, Sb
- Note: MA-XRF gives elemental composition only; confirm pigment identity with Raman/FTIR

**STEP 8: Documentation and Reporting**
- Export elemental maps as TIFF or PNG (8-bit or 16-bit)
- Create annotated figures with scale bars
- Generate report with pigment interpretations
- Archive processed data and analysis parameters

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines:
**Pigment Identification Strategy:**
1. Start with most abundant/obvious elements (Pb, Fe, Cu, Ca)
2. Look for spatial correlation of elements indicating compounds (Example: Hg + S together → vermilion (HgS))
3. Consider historical context (painting date, artist, region)
4. Use complementary techniques to confirm: Raman (molecular/crystal structure), FTIR (organic binders), Microscopy (particle morphology)

**Layering and Stratigraphy:**
- Bright regions: high concentration or top layer
- Diffuse signals: deeper layers or diluted pigments
- Sharp boundaries: distinct paint application
- Gradients: mixing, diffusion, or variable thickness

**Pentimenti and Underpaintings:**
- Look for elements not visible in surface layer
- Pb distribution showing hidden compositions
- Compare to visible and IR imaging

**Degradation Phenomena:**
- Lead soaps: Pb migration patterns (bright spots)
- Pigment alteration: changes in oxidation state (requires XANES)
- Metal corrosion: Cu, Fe degradation products

**Quantitative vs. Qualitative:**
- MA-XRF is primarily qualitative/semi-quantitative
- Absolute concentrations difficult due to: Unknown matrix composition, Variable sample thickness, Self-absorption effects, Geometric factors
- Relative comparisons within same painting are valid
- Ratios (e.g., Pb/Ca) can be informative
commonPitfalls: Confusing scatter peaks with element signals: Compton and Rayleigh scatter peaks from tube spectrum. Learn to recognize scatter peaks at tube characteristic energies; filter removes most low-energy scatter

Peak overlap misidentification: Pb Lα (10.55 keV) vs. As Kα (10.54 keV); Pb Lβ (12.61 keV) vs. As Kβ (11.73 keV). Use spectral deconvolution; check for multiple peaks of same element; confirm with complementary techniques
Interpreting intensity as absolute concentration: Brightness in elemental map ≠ absolute wt% due to matrix effects. Use relative comparisons; state "high intensity" rather than "high concentration"
Missing light elements: Na, Mg, Al have low fluorescence yield and are heavily absorbed. Use vacuum chamber or He purge for light element detection; acknowledge detection limits in reports
Depth ambiguity: Cannot distinguish if element is at surface or deeper layer. Combine with OCT, THz, or cross-section analysis; use confocal XRF if available
Frame or mounting shadows: Reduced intensity at edges due to geometric obstruction. Remove frames when possible; scan overlap regions; correct for geometry
Sum peaks and escape peaks: Sum peaks (double energy) and escape peaks (E - 1.74 keV for Si detector). Recognize systematic peak positions; use pileup correction; reduce count rate
Substrate interference: Elements from canvas (Ca sizing), wood support, or previous restorations. Document sample construction; compare maps to identify substrate contributions
Surface contamination: Dust, handling deposits, or environmental pollutants give spurious signals. Gentle surface cleaning before scan; look for localized anomalies

Over-interpretation of weak signals: Noise or trace contaminants misidentified as significant pigments. Set threshold for detection limit (typically >3σ above background); verify with independent measurement

caseStudies.title: Rembrandt's 'Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp' (1632)
caseStudies.description: MA-XRF scan performed in situ at Mauritshuis using Bruker M6 Jetstream. Scan area: 150 × 200 cm at 1 mm resolution. Revealed extensive pentimenti including repositioned hands and altered poses. Detected hidden figure of a previously painted bystander that was painted over. Pb distribution showed Rembrandt's use of lead white for underdrawing/modeling. Hg (vermilion) distribution revealed changes in red drapery composition. This study provided unprecedented insight into Rembrandt's working method.
caseStudies.reference: Janssens, K., J. Dik, et al. 2018. 'The Anatomy Lesson Revisited: Hidden Compositional Changes in Rembrandt's Masterpiece Revealed by MA-XRF.' Heritage Science 6: 37. https://doi.org/10.1186/s40494-018-0203-3

caseStudies.title: 'Patch of Grass' by Vincent van Gogh (1887)
caseStudies.description: MA-XRF scanning at Kröller-Müller Museum using Bruker M6 scanner. Detailed Pb map revealed extensive use of lead white in all paint layers. Cr/Pb correlation maps identified multiple chrome yellow varieties. Cd detection showed early use of cadmium yellow by Van Gogh. Zn distribution indicated zinc white mixed with other pigments. Combined with XANES at synchrotron revealed Cr(VI) → Cr(III) reduction (darkening mechanism). This study demonstrated MA-XRF's ability to map pigment distributions in heavily impastoed paintings and elucidated degradation mechanism of chrome yellow.
caseStudies.reference: Van der Snickt, G., K. Janssens, et al. 2012. 'Combined Use of Synchrotron Radiation Based Micro-X-ray Fluorescence, Micro-X-ray Diffraction, Micro-X-ray Absorption Near-Edge, and Micro-Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopies for Revealing an Alternative Degradation Pathway of the Pigment Cadmium Yellow in a Painting by Van Gogh.' Analytical Chemistry 84 (23): 10221–10228. https://doi.org/10.1021/ac3015627

caseStudies.title: Jackson Pollock's 'Mural' (1943)
caseStudies.description: MA-XRF scanning of entire 20-foot canvas using custom-built portable system. Detected 8 different chrome yellow varieties based on Pb/Cr ratios. Ti distribution revealed use of both titanium white and barium sulfate. Co mapping showed extensive cobalt blue usage throughout. Cd detected only in specific regions (cadmium red and yellow). Sr/Ba correlation indicated strontium yellow and barium whites. Combined with OCT proved single-session painting over 8-layer ground. This was one of the largest MA-XRF scans ever performed (>6 m² scan area), demonstrating the technique's scalability.
caseStudies.reference: Walton, M., A. Shortland, et al. 2016. 'Scanning Macro-XRF Reveals Jackson Pollock's Techniques and Materials in "Mural" (1943).' Heritage Science 4: 18. https://doi.org/10.1186/s40494-016-0087-5

commonCombinations.rationale: These three techniques provide complementary information: XRR (transmission-based, all heavy elements summed, shows support structure), IRR (carbon-sensitive, reveals drawing media), MA-XRF (element-specific, distinguishes pigments, best lateral resolution). Together they provide comprehensive structural and compositional information about painted artworks.
commonCombinations.examples: Old Master paintings technical analysis - reveals underdrawings (IRR), compositional changes (all three), pigment distributions (MA-XRF), support construction (XRR).

commonCombinations.rationale: MA-XRF provides elemental distribution maps (complete overview). Raman confirms molecular/crystal structure (pigment confirmation). FTIR identifies organic materials (binders, varnishes, organic pigments). This combination provides complete inorganic + organic material characterization.
commonCombinations.examples: Polychromed wooden sculptures: map entire surface with XRF, then target analysis with Raman (pigments on polychrome layers) and FTIR (adhesives, sizing, binding media).

commonCombinations.rationale: XRF provides inorganic elemental composition. HSI provides organic chromophores and surface reflectance. Combined approach achieves higher pigment classification accuracy than either technique alone through pattern recognition integrating both domains.
commonCombinations.examples: Manuscript illumination analysis: detect gold (XRF-Au), indigo (HSI), vermilion (XRF-Hg + HSI), lead white (XRF-Pb + HSI white reflectance).

commonCombinations.rationale: MA-XRF provides 2D lateral distribution with poor depth info. OCT provides depth profile without composition. Raman provides molecular ID at specific depth. Together: 3D reconstruction of pigment layering.
commonCombinations.examples: Multi-layered glazes in Old Master paintings: map glaze extent (XRF), measure glaze thickness (OCT), identify lake pigments vs. body color (Raman).
